abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is highly
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, with substantial
            institutional development impacts. Although project
            preparation, and appraisal took longer than anticipated, it
            proved essential in ensuring full agreement between the
            Borrower and the Bank on issues related to project
            objectives, content, and design. In line with the above,
            lessons demonstrate that the Borrower's sustained
            commitments, and the Bank's readiness to adjust
            implementation arrangements, were instrumental for the
            success of the project, particularly so for the land survey
            program, drainage rehabilitation, and advisory services
            components. Nonetheless, assumptions regarding the impact of
            transition to a market economy, as it regards the evolving
            structure of the rural economy proved inaccurate, suggesting
            forecasts be regarded as transient. Evolution of the framing
            sector was faster than foreseen, with implications for the
            advisory services component, e.g., responsiveness to the
            evolving land, and tax policy required modifications in the
            implementation of the land reform component. However,
            project experience also shows that effective private-public
            partnerships can meet satisfactory information needs, with a
            quick adaptation to changing client characteristics, and needs.
